metadata.title: Binary Search in Python — Is it Faster? | by Martin Andersson Aaberge | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Binary Search in Python — Is it Faster?
metadata.description: Binary Search is an algorithm that will perform a search faster than a linear search, but not always. Let's have a look at some examples in Python.

all_paragraphs: It’s that time of the week! You decide to dive deeper into a subject and today we are looking at Binary Search.

As always, there are many ways to solve the same problem. When you want to check if an element is in a list, you can do this with a linear search as well as a binary search, but guess which is faster.
If you have watched programming job interviews on Youtube lately, you know that binary search is a favorite.

Why should you spend time learning about binary search? Your C++ programming friends probably told you this already. Python is slow. You want to make sure you don’t make your program slower than it needs to be.
When you learn Python, you learn to do a linear search to check if an element is in a list. That’s fine when you learn to code, but what happens when you have 60.000.000 elements in a list?

If you do a linear search in a list with 11 elements you have to go through all 11 elements. If you use binary search you might end up with as few as 2 iterations depending on what you’re looking for. See the graphics below.
It should be obvious which approach is faster.
You have most likely worked with lists a hundred times already when you started learning Python. Checking if a value is in the list is a normal task and you have seen this before:
Let’s start looking at how you can implement binary search.
Let’s visualize how binary search works.

First, we need to make sure the list is sorted. You can sort your list with either .sort() or sorted() I use .sort() to alter the list in place. If you for some reason need a new list or don’t want to tamper with the original, use sorted()
We are going to look for the value 15.
How do you think the algorithm would behave if we were looking for 2, and our first middle value was 9? You’re right. The max index would move instead.

Now let’s run it 60 million times! Just kidding, I trust these results. MacBooks are expensive.
Is binary faster than linear, then? Yes, but it depends.
When someone tells you binary search is faster, it is because it generally is.
As always, you have to look at the setting and don’t go for a single solution every time because it “is the best”.

What we saw from our experiments, was that it depends on what you are doing. If you have a short list, or if you are looking for an element in the lower part of a list, you might be better off performing a linear search.

This is also the beauty of programming. You aren’t supposed to use one way of doing something without knowing why you are doing it. If you didn’t know binary search already, now you have yet another tool to do a search. Use it whenever you find a good use for it.
I hope we can agree on one thing though. Binary Search is pretty darn cool!
